citations.narrative:
The inventory of animals on hand did not include all animals viewed on the inspection. Facilities must make, keep and
maintain records of all animals owned and held in their possession. Failure to maintain current and accurate records
prevents APHIS officials from verifying the sources and destinations of animals held at a facility. The facility must ensure
the inventory is kept up to date. To be corrected by November 28, 2024.

There were several outdoor enclosures housing animals that were in need of repair:
1. There was one section of fencing at the bottom of an enclosure housing 1 eland that was in poor repair, creating
several sharp pieces of wire that could potentially be accessed by the animal.
2. There was one small section of fencing at the bottom of an enclosure housing 6 elk that was in disrepair, creating
several sharp points that could potentially be accessed by the animals.
3. There were two sections of fencing at the bottom of an enclosure housing 1 cattle that had been damaged and pulled
back, exposing several sharp points.
Sharp points and edges have the potential to injure animals. The facility must ensure that outdoor housing facilities are
maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. To be corrected by November 14, 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
Enclosures housing two scarlet macaws and two umbrella cockatoos did not contain any enrichment items, in
contravention to the facility-supplied environment enhancement plan for birds. Although these were not permanent
enclosures, birds must be provided with environmental enhancement as specified by the facility's environment
enhancement plan for birds. Birds that are not provided with consistent environmental enhancement may become
stressed and develop behavioral problems. The facility must ensure that it follows a species-appropriate plan for
environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. To be corrected by November 7,
2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The inventory of animals on hand did not include all animals viewed on the inspection. Facilities must make, keep and 
maintain records of all animals owned and held in their possession. Failure to maintain current and accurate records 
prevents APHIS officials from verifying the sources and destinations of animals held at a facility. The facility must ensure 
the inventory is kept up to date. To be corrected by November 28, 2024. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
There were several outdoor enclosures housing animals that were in need of repair: 
 
1. There was one section of fencing at the bottom of an enclosure housing 1 eland that was in poor repair, creating 
several sharp pieces of wire that could potentially be accessed by the animal.  
2. There was one small section of fencing at the bottom of an enclosure housing 6 elk that was in disrepair, creating 
several sharp points that could potentially be accessed by the animals.  
3. There were two sections of fencing at the bottom of an enclosure housing 1 cattle that had been damaged and pulled 
back, exposing several sharp points.  
 
Sharp points and edges have the potential to injure animals. The facility must ensure that outdoor housing facilities are 
maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. To be corrected by November 14, 2024. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
Enclosures housing two scarlet macaws and two umbrella cockatoos did not contain any enrichment items, in 
contravention to the facility-supplied environment enhancement plan for birds. Although these were not permanent 
enclosures, birds must be provided with environmental enhancement as specified by the facility's environment 
enhancement plan for birds. Birds that are not provided with consistent environmental enhancement may become 
stressed and develop behavioral problems. The facility must ensure that it follows a species-appropriate plan for

environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. To be corrected by November 7, 
2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
